Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

Desde hace 15 años en la ciudad de Chinandega en el mercado central, la señora Mercedes P. se dedica a la venta de ropa de todos tamaños y para todas las edades. Posee un tramo propio el cual le ha costado mucha inversión y por ser una madre soltera y con un hijo pequeño a que mantener ha logrado surtir de mayores cantidades de ropa su negocio.

El negocio lo comienza hace 5 años vendiendo ambulante en todo el mercado, exponiéndose al sol y al desgaste físico producidos por el caminar mucho. Poco a poco comenzó a invertir para pagar un local interno en el mercado hasta que lo obtuvo. Desde que logró obtener el tramo en el mercado ha realizado créditos en Ceprodel que le han impactado grandemente por el hecho de que ha comprado mayores volúmenes de ropa para ofrecer y además ha podido sostener el núcleo de su hogar por ser madre soltera y con un pequeño hijo a quien mantener.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing to resell.

loans.name: Nevzija

texts.en: Nevzija was born in 1949 and she lives in Živinice. She has a husband who has been retired for 17 years. His pension is about US$ 225. They are doing agricultural work  and selling used clothes. This is her second loan at MCO WWI. Her first loan  was for US$ 450. She intends to use her second loan in the amount of US$ 925 for buying more clothes for re-sale  and buying some chickens. She thinks  that she will be able to improve  their monthly household income.

loans.use: Buying clothes and chickens

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
Two years ago Pedro’s father passed away. Despite the pain of losing his father, Pedro immediately began to sell cosmetics by catalogue. He did this to pay for his studies, which his father had paid before. Little by little and with the help of some female friends, Pedro began to understand this branch of the cosmetics market.

Currently Pedro has various female clients, clients from his university, and his small city. Still, although Pedro has numerous clients requesting products, he currently lacks the inventory to supply to them. For this reason Pedro is requesting a credit of $375. This loan he agrees to repay within 6 months. With the loan he will purchase the requested products for sale to his clients.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

Hace dos años que el papá D. Pedro desgraciadamente falleció y a pesar del dolor D. perder a su padre, comenzó a vender cosméticos por catálogo para poder seguir costeando sus estudios. Puesto que su papá era quien le pagaba los estudios. Poco a poco y con la ayuda D. sus amigas, comenzó a conocer esta rama D. los cosméticos.

Actualmente, tiene varias clientas y clientes D. su universidad y D. su colonia. Sin embargo actualmente no cuenta con la mercancía que le están solicitando es por eso que Pedro está pidiendo un crédito D. US $375 que está dispuesto a pagarlos en un plazo D. 6 meses y con este dinero Pedro podrá comprar los productos que le están solicitando.

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetic items for resale.

loans.name: Julia De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
Julia is a hard working woman and since 1970 has dedicated herself to selling a variety of vegetables in the central market of Chinandega. She characterized herself as happy and humble. She started her business with savings of C$ 1500 (approximately $80 US) which she had accumulated over a long period of time.

She is the mother of 2 children (a daughter and a son) that she would like to offer an education as they are minors. Her biggest dream is to prepare her children to have professions so they don't have to suffer like she did since childhood working hard labor. To realize this dream, Julia has for the past 3 years obtained loans through Ceprodel which have helped her acquire more vegetables thus increasing her profits as well as improving her way of life and that of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva volunteer.

Julia es una dama muy trabajadora que desde el año 1970 se dedica a la venta de verduras de todo tipo en el mercado central en Chinandega. Se caracteriza por ser una dama muy alegre y humilde. Su negocio lo comenzó con un capital propio de C$ 1500 (Mil quinientos córdobas netos) obtenidos por medio de sus ahorros propios de largo tiempo.

Actualmente es madre de dos hijos (un niño y una niña) los cuales tiene el deber de brindarles educación ya que son menores de edad. Su mayor anhelo es que sus hijos se preparen para poder ser profesionales y no sufrir como ella considera que sufrió desde muy joven con trabajos muy pesados. Para ver logrado este sueño, la señora Julia desde hace tres años, ha obtenido prestamos en Ceprodel que le han beneficiado grandemente en la adquisición de las verduras impactándole con altos beneficios ya que ha logrado mejorar sus condiciones de vida y las de su familia.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables.

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Phạm Thị Nụ is 24. She became a TYM member 4 years ago. She is married and has 2 children aged 7 and 2. They live in Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa province (south of Ha Noi). After discussing with her husband, she has decided to start a farm supplies business selling fertilizer. She is a trusty person so her store attracts a lot of customers. Her business is growing so she decides to add "nứa" (a kind of bamboo) to her inventory. Her husband is a truck driver, transporting goods for those companies in the area. Their family income is quite stable. Together they make 350-400 USD a month. This time she is requesting a loan of 950 USD to replenish her inventory to get ready for the upcoming season.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Phạm Thị Nụ, 28 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ tới nay được 4 năm. Gia đình chị gồm 4 người, 2 vợ chồng và 2 con: 7 tuổi và 2 tuổi, đang sinh sống tại Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Sẵn có địa điểm đẹp, chị Nụ bàn với chồng mở cửa hàng bán đạm lân. Luôn giữ chữ tín nên cửa hàng của chị lúc nào cũng đông khách đến mua. Thấy công việc bán hàng thuận lợi, chị Nụ quyết định mua thêm nứa bán cho người dân làm nghề phu. Chồng chị là một lái xe tải, chuyên chở hàng cho các đại lý, kho, bãi trong vùng nên thu nhập cũng khá ổn định. Bình quân một tháng gia đình thu từ 350-400USD. Lần này chị Nụ quyết định vay 950USD để mua thêm hàng dự trữ cho mùa tới.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer

loans.name: Gerardo Antonio

texts.es:
Mr. Gerardo C. sells vegetables and fruits in the central market of Chinandega. He began by selling his products in the bus terminals, but over time decided to seek financing in order to move his business to a fixed location of his own.

Mr. C. credits the loans he has previously received from CEPRODEL, and thus the installation of his business in a fixed location, for the profound increase in his quality of life. It is his principle dream to continue bettering his business and increase the quality of life for his two parents who have entered into old age. Currently his building is not in the best of shape, the roof is constructed of plastic and there are no walls. Mr. C. does not lose hope in the face of these problems, instead he hopes that one day he will be able to better the conditions of his business through the continued help from CEPRODEL.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

El Sr. Gerardo Chavarría se dedica a la actividad de venta de verduras y frutas en el mercado central del departamento de Chinandega. en un inicio oferta sus productos ambulantes en la terminales de buses pero en el transcurso del tiempo decide solicitar financiamiento para instalar su negocio en un local propio.

Manifiesta el Sr. Chavarrìa que el aporte económico que la han brindado en CEPRODEL ha sido decisivo en el desarrollo de su actividad por el motivo de que le ha permitido mejorar la calidad de vida ya que ahora tiene un local propio y uno de sus mayores sueños es mejorar las condiciones de su local así como mejorar las condiciones de vida de sus padres los cuales ya son adultos mayores. Actualmente su local no presenta buenas condiciones el techo es de plástico y no hay paredes pero no pierde la esperanza en que algún día mejorara estas condiciones gracias al apoyo que le continue brindando Ceprodel.

loans.use: Purchase of vegetables and fruits, along with improvements to the building.

loans.name: Obelisco Group

texts.en:
The community bank Obelisco was started seven years ago. It now has 20 associates, all of whom are from the town of Quinua. Quinua is the town where South America won its independence and is now known as the home of artisans who make beautiful ceramics.

Through the bank they have learned to save and to be punctual and responsible. They have also learned about self esteem, being independent, and working outsiD. of the home. Many of the associates have different businesses. Most make ceramics, but others carve alabaster, raise animals, grind flour, own grocery stores, or sell juices, food, fruits, and vegetables.

Each member has a different history he or she could tell. For example, Juana makes beautiful ceramics. She learned this skill from her husband, who has been practicing all his life. Or there is Erasma G., who used to grow herbs and raise animals, but with a loan from the community bank was able to buy a gas stove and begin to sell the delicious foods she had been making for years.

The associates need loans of different amounts ranging from 300 to 900 soles (3 soles = about $1), making a total of 10,250 soles. They will invest their loans in buying things such as fruits, vegetables, clay, dyes, seeds, flour, and sugar.

They will use their savings to educate their children, build houses, and continue to develop their businesses. They have many dreams, such as seeing their children become professionals, completing their homes, and finishing a biology degree and opening a local clinic.

loans.use: For the 20 associates to invest in buying things such as fruits, vegetables, clay, dyes, seeds, flour, and sugar

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Tran Thi C., 35 years old, lives with her husband and two small children in Quang Xuong district, Thanh Hoa province. Besides farming and breeding animals, Mrs. C.'s main job is to buy and sell birds. This job brings pretty high profit (compared to the small amount of fund needed). In the village there are people who often set snares to catch birds. She buys birds from them, sort them out, and then resell them to customers. Before, when she doesn't have much capital, she buys cheap birds. This time she would like to borrow 825 USD to buy more expensive birds. Her family monthly income is 200 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Trần Thị Cảnh, 35 tuổi, sống cùng chồng và hai con nhỏ tại Quảng Xương. Bên cạnh công việc của một người phụ nữ nông thôn là làm ruộng và chăn nuôi, nghề chính của chị Cảnh là buôn bán chim cảnh. Đây là một nghề mang lại lợi nhuận khá cao so với đồng vốn bỏ ra. Chị Cảnh thường mua chim của những người đi đánh bẫy, sau đó phân loại và bán lại cho những người có nhu cầu chơi chim. Khi trước vốn ít chị chỉ buôn những loại chim bình thường, đến vòng vốn này chị bàn với chồng và quyết định vay mức vốn 825USD để mua được nhiều loại chim quý hơn. Thu nhập bình quân của cả gia đình là 200USD/tháng.

loans.use: Buy birds

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana S. is single. She lives with her parents in downtown Berdyansk. Tatyana sells butter, cheese and meat in the central city market. Her kiosk is well known among customers for prices that are usually lower than those of other vendors. Tatyana has always been very honest and fair with each of her clients, which has helped her gain a good reputation and find many loyal customers. Presently, her turnover capital is about $2000. Tatyana has about $500 in inventory. Her monthly net profit is around $600.  

Tatyana is requesting a loan of $1000 to increase her assorted inventory, add to her turnover capital and reconstruct her vending facility. She has good management skills, a committed attitude and huge business potential. We believe the consistency and sustainability of Tatyana’s business, her knowledge of the market and her friendliness with clients will help her continue to be successful and repay this loan.

loans.use: To reconstruct her vending facility and increase  stock

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es:
Eight years ago Maria Elena and her husband were unable to repay the debts they had, given the fact that her husband didn’t even earn enough to cover the expenses of their home and children. With no other option, Maria began to sell pastries to her neighbors. She offered the service for parties and other social events. Little by little Maria became more well- known and gained clientele.

Regardless of the increased business, Maria finds herself low on certain basic items, molds, and other accessories for the production of pastries. Items which give the pastries that extra touch and presentation. For this reason Maria is requesting a loan of $475, which she agrees to repay in six months. She intends to purchase the necessary items to truly impress her clients with her pastries. With your help Maria Elena will be able to better her entire family.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

Hace 8 años que María Elena no encontraba la manera de terminar con las deudas que tenía puesto que con lo que gana su esposo no es suficiente para poder pagar los gastos de la casa y los gastos de sus hijos. Fue así como comenzó a hacer pasteles para venderles a sus vecinas. Ofreciendo el servicio para fiestas y eventos sociales. Poco a poco María fue haciéndose conocida y actualmente ya tiene varios pedidos.

Sin embargo A María le hacen falta unas bases, y fuentes o accesorios para poder ponerle a los pasteles y así darles una mejor presentación. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $475 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero María podrá comprar las bases y los accesorios para que sus clientes queden satisfechos con los pasteles. Con tu ayuda María Elena podrá sacar adelante a su familia.

loans.use: Purchase of basic items and accessories for the production of pastries.

loans.name: Cao Thi

texts.vi:
This is the fourh year that Mrs. Cao Thi H., 29 years old, is a member of TYM Fund (Kiva's partner). She lives with her husband and two children in Quang Xuong District, Thanh Hoa Province. Since her two children are still small, Mrs. H. lives at home to breed animals and do farming. Her main family income is from her small motorbike repair shop. Mr. Thanh, her husband is the main mechanic, and she helps out with the job. Most of Vietnamese population use motorbikes, so her job at the repair shop brings a pretty steady income to her family. Each month they earn about 100USD. In order to increase their income, she needs to have more inventories at hand. That is why she applies for a loan of 525 USD to buy more motorbike parts. Mrs. H. hopes to increase their family income to 125-150 USD per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by PH. Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Cao Thị Hương, 29 tuổi, là thành viên năm thứ 4 của Quỹ Tình thương. Chị sống cùng chồng và 2 con tại Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Do hai con còn nhỏ nên chị Hương ở nhà chăn nuôi và làm ruộng. Nguồn thu chính của gia đình chị Hương là từ cửa hàng sửa chữa xe máy. Anh Thanh, chồng chị là người sửa chữa chính còn chị là người phụ giúp. Hiện nay việc đi lại bằng xe máy đã phổ biến nên việc sửa chữa, bảo dưỡng xe mang lại cho gia đình một khoản thu nhập tương đối ổn định. Thu nhập từ cửa hàng một tháng khoảng 100USD. Để nâng cao thu nhập cần có nhiều phụ tùng sửa chữa, thay thế khi khách hàng cần nên đến vòng vốn này chị Hương đã xin vay 525USD để mua thêm phụ tùng. Chị hy vọng sẽ nâng thu nhập lên mức 125-150USD/tháng.

loans.use: Buy motorbike parts

loans.name: Doan Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Doan Thi N., 57 years old, lives with her husband (a farmer) and her only son in Quang Xuong province. Her income is mainly from gardening and breeding animals, and Mrs. N. uses most of her loan from TYM Fund (Kiva's partner) on these. She always has a litter of pigs in her house (one litter after another). Often, she sells her pigs every three months and gets 500-700 USD. Her son is working to help pay for her weekly repayment. Her husband also helps out with her work and her repayment. With the support from her family, she intends to borrow 525 USD to buy more piglets because she just sold one litter of pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Doãn Thị Nhạn, 57 tuổi, sống cùng với cùng với chồng, một nông dân, và người con trai duy nhất tại Quảng Xương. Thu nhập của gia đình chị chủ yếu từ trồng trọt và chăn nuôi, vì vậy phần lớn những đồng vốn vay từ Quỹ đều được chị sử dụng cho mục đích này. Trong chuồng nhà chị lúc nào cũng có một đàn lợn bán, lứa này lại có lứa khác thay thế. Bình thường khoảng 3 tháng chị Nhạn lại bán một lứa lợn cho thu nhập khoảng 500-700USD. Tiền hoàn trả hàng tuần do con chị đi làm trả. Chồng chị cũng phụ giúp chị trong công việc gia đình cũng như hoàn trả tuần. Với sự ủng hộ từ phía gia đình, vòng vốn này chị Nhạn xin vay 525USD để mua lợn con thay cho lứa lợn vừa bán.

loans.use: Buy pigs

loans.name: Claudia Iveth

texts.es:
Five years ago, Claudia received the news that she was pregnant, whice was good news for her and her husband. It became even more wonderful when they found out they were having twins. However, Claudia began to realize that they did not have the necessary means to support two children. This is why she searched for ways to increase their income while still taking care of her children. Claudia started selling barbecue and menudo (typical Mexican dish). Little by little, Claudia became known for her excellent food.

Today she has a large clientele, but she can't keep up with demand. This is why she's asking for a $475 loan that will be repaid in 6 months. With this loan, Claudia will be able to buy more equipment to prepare larger quantites of food. With your help Claudia will be able to push her children ahead in life.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva volunteer.

Hace 5 años que le dieron la noticia a Claudia de que estaba embarazada, para ella y su esposo fue muy buena noticia. Y se convirtió en mejor noticia al enterarse de que eran dos. Sin embargo Claudia comenzó a ver que no contaban con recursos suficientes para poder pagar los gastos de dos hijos. Fue por eso que buscó la manera de obtener mayores ingresos, sin descuidar a sus hijos, Claudia comenzó a elaborar barbacoa y menudo en su casa para vender. Poco a poco Claudia comenzó a hacerse conocida por el buen sabor de sus comidas.

Actualmente ya cuenta con gran variedad de clientes. Sin embargo la mercancía que puede fabricar no es suficiente para poder venderle a sus clientes. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $475 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses con este dinero Claudia podrá comprar unas vaporeras para elaborar más mercancía. Con tu ayuda Claudia podrá sacar adelante a sus hijos.

loans.use: To buy more equipment.

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is married with two children. Her family lives in Mukachevo, where Nataliya runs a small business selling leather purses and wallets in the local shopping mall. She has been in this trade for 10 years. Her business venture has been marked by stability and high demand for all her inventory. Currently, Nataliya has about $800 in inventory on hand. 

Nataliya would like to get a loan of $1200 to increase her turnover capital and assorted inventory. She has invested tremendous effort in her trade and is not going to stop where she is at right now. Nataliya believes that her business and marketing abilities, in combination with financial assistance, will help increase her income and success.

loans.use: To increase inventory and turnover capital

loans.name: Erlinda's Group

texts.en:
Erlinda, Lourdes, and Marisol have been part of the community bank Golondrinas for three, one, and two years, respectively. In their community bank they have learned how to educate their children, how to have a positive relationship with their husbands, and the importance of saving.

Erlinda is 25 years old. She lives with her partner and two children. Erlinda has been selling clothing for one year. Previously, she traveled to various markets around the region buying grains and then selling them in Ayacucho. She decided to start a new business in order to spend more time with her children.

Similarly, Lourdes is 24 and lives with her partner and two children. She sells cellular phones from a stand located in the central plaza of Ayacuhco. Before doing that she sold juices from a cart. She is now able to make more money with her new business.

Marisol is 34 years old. She is married and also has two children. Marisol has been selling clothing for close to 18 months. In addition, she knits alpaca sweaters, which she sends to an intermediary in Lima.

Erlinda, Lourdes, and Marisol need loans of 800, 800, and 1000 soles (3 soles = about $1), which they will use to invest in buying pants, sweaters, shirts, underwear, jackets, and cell phones for their businesses.

Erlinda, Lourdes, and Marisol are all saving to buy a house and a piece of land. Their dreams are to own a clothing store, continue to develop their businesses, and give their children a good education.

loans.use: To buy pants, sweaters, shirts, underwear, jackets, and cell phones to sell

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Pham Thi T., 56 years old, lives with her husband and her youngest child who is a high school senior. Her other three children already have a job and move out. Besides farming on a couple of perches of rice-field, her family main job is breeding animals. With the advantage of having quite a lot of land, Mrs. T. breeds 200 ducks. This brings her a steady income. Each day she gets around 100 duck eggs. She then brings these eggs to sell in the market and earn 6-8 USD. She uses this money to repay her loan quickly and still has enough left for her daily expenses. Besides, she also breeds 4-5 pigs. Because of the increase in the animals leading to larger demand on feedings for them, Mrs. T. wants to borrow 575 USD to buy food for her ducks and pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Phạm Thị Thành, 56 tuổi, đang sống cùng chồng và người con út đang học năm cuối phổ thông. 3 người con lớn đều trưởng thành, có việc làm và đã ra ở riêng. Ngoài việc làm vài sào ruông, hoạt động chính của gia đình là chăn nuôi. Tận dụng lợi thế diện tích đất rộng, chị Thành nuôi khoảng 200 con vịt đẻ. Đây là một công việc mang lại lợi nhuận rất thường xuyên. Số trứng thu hoạch mỗi ngày khoảng hơn 100 quả mang ra chợ bán được từ 6-8USD. Số tiền vừa giúp chị thuận lợi cho việc hoàn trả tuần và đủ trang trải khoản chi phí sinh hoạt gia đình. Ngoài ra chị còn chăn nuôi 4-5 con lợn. Số lượng đàn gia súc, gia cầm lớn nên để có đủ cám, thức ăn tổng hợp gia súc chị Thành đã làm đơn xin vay 575USD trong vòng vốn tới.

loans.use: Buy food for ducks, pigs

loans.name: Feliciana Isabel

texts.es:
Felicita P. is a lady who all her life has lived in the beautiful department of León in Nicaragua. When she was young, she learned from her mother about making edible products out of corn, for example, a drink called chicha, tortillas and powder for drinks, etc.

It should be pointed out that Mrs. P. is an excellent cook and because of that, she has seen her business overcome with many clients, who are in the habit of consuming these products made from corn. In spite of her clientele, Mrs. P. faces the need to invest in her business and that is why she turns to Ceprodel, who has helped her with a total of 25 loans invested directly in the purchase of corn and firewood, which is her current need.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

Felicita P. es una dama que toda su vida la ha vivido en el bello departamento de León en Nicaragua. Desde muy joven aprendió de su madre la elaboración de productos comestibles derivados del maíz como por ejemplo el refresco de chicha, tortillas y bebida en polvo, etc.

Cabe señalar que la señora P. es una excelente cocinera y por tal razón, su negocio se ha visto invadido de muchos clientes que tienen como habito consumir estos productos derivados del maíz. A pesar de su clientela, la señora P. atraviesa la necesidad de invertir en su negocio y para esto es que acude a Ceprodel que le ha apoyado con un total de 25 créditos invertidos directamente para la compra del maíz y la leña que es su necesidad en la actualidad.

loans.use: Sale of corn products.

loans.name: Phan Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Phan Thị Q. is 42 years old. She lives in Quảng Xương. She is a TYM fund member for 5 years now. She has 3 children (2 are still attending school). Her main occupation is selling pork. Her husband buys the pigs and butchers them, she sells the pork. This is why they make more profit than their peers. Each month, on average, they make 200-250 USD. Since now is the year end (lunar calendar), the demand is rising. Mrs Q. thinks that they need to stock up to meet the demand because of the upcoming Tết Nguyên Đán festivities. After discussing with her husband, she has decided to apply for a loan of 575 USD to invest into their business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Phan Thị Q., 42 tuổi, đang sống tại Quảng Xương, là thành viên năm thứ 5 của Quỹ Tình thương. 2 trong số 3 người con của chị hiện vẫn đang học phổ thông. Công việc chính hiện nay của gia đình chị Q. là bán thịt lợn. Chồng mua lợn về giết mổ, vợ bán thịt, nên lợi nhuận cao hơn so với những người phải đi nhập hàng từ nơi khác về. Trung bình một tháng gia đình thu khoảng 200-250USD. Vào dịp cuối năm, nhu cầu thực phẩm của người dân tăng cao, chị Q. thấy cần phải tăng thêm lượng hàng phục vụ cho Tết nguyên đán. Chị đã bàn với chồng và Q.ết định vay 575USD đầu tư cho việc buôn bán.

loans.use: Buy pigs

loans.name: Benjamín

texts.es:
When he married, Benjamín was a construction worker. However as his three daughters began to grow up the money he made was not enough to pay for the expenses of his home. He decided to rent a taxi to increase his income. Litlle by little he saved enough money to purchase his own taxi and he currently owns his vehicle.

Unfortunately his taxi needs to be repaired. To repair his taxi Benjamín is requesting a microloan of US $650 to be paid back in six months. With the money he will be able to repair and paint his taxi which will allow him to continue paying for his three girls´ schooling. With your help Benjamin´s daughters will be able to earn a degree and have a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.<

loans.use: Repair and paint his taxi

loans.name: Nancy's Group

texts.en:
Giovanna, Elsa, and Nancy have been part of the community bank Amaquella, which means, “don’t be lazy,” in Quechua, for one year, eight months, and three years, respectively. In their community bank they have learned how to educate their children, the importance of being punctual, the incentives of saving, and how to work together with the other associates.

Giovanna is 33 years old. She is a single mother of one son. Giovanna sells meat from a stand in the Magdalena market. She has had this business for six years.

Elsa is 32 and lives with her partner and one child. She sells cosmetics from a catalog to her family and friends.

Nancy is 33 years old. She is the single mother of two children. Nancy has a restaurant that serves chicken located on a main street of Ayacucho.

Giovanna, Elsa, and Nancy need loans of 600, 600, and 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying mutton, pork, perfumes, cosmetics, shampoo, rice, sugar, noodles, oil, milk, salt, and vegetables.

The community bank emphasizes the importance of saving, and each associate has an interest-earning savings account. Giovanna, Elsa, and Nancy plan to use their savings to help their children, to use if there is an emergency, and to expand their businesses. Their dreams are to own their businesses, each own a house, and open other branches, and that their children will study and be good people.

loans.use: For the three women to buy supplies for their businesses

loans.name: Trinh Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Trinh Thi T., 52 years old, joined the TYM Fund since 2002. Her family has 7 members: the parents and 5 children, 3 of which are going T. school. She uses the money borrowed from the Fund T. breed animals. T. be able T. repay weekly, she weaves the baskets and sell them. Selling 7-8 baskets/ week will help her repay weekly. This is also the money resource for her family living cost. Besides, Mr. Xuyen, Mrs. T.’s husband is a building worker. Therefore, her family income is pretty stable. Her wish is T. see her children growing up educatedly. Even during difficult time, she still managed T. send her children T. school. This time, she wants T. borrow 575 USD T. buy more piglets, pig mash and bamboo T. weave baskets. Her current income is 150 USD/month. 
Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Trịnh Thị Tơ, 52 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ Tình thương năm 2002. Gia đình chị gồm 2 vợ chồng và 5 người con, trong đó 3 người đang đi học. Vốn vay từ Quỹ được chị sử dụng chủ yếu cho việc chăn nuôi. Để có nguồn hoàn trả hàng tuần chị Tơ đan thúng bán, chỉ 7-8 cái thúng là đủ tiền trả hàng tuần. Đây cũng là nguồn chi cho tiêu dùng hàng ngày của gia đình. Bên cạnh đó anh Xuyến, chồng chị đi làm thợ xây nên việc chi tiêu trong gia đình cũng ổn định. Mong muốn của chị Tơ là được thấy con cái trưởng thành nên người, nên ngay trong nhưng lúc khó khăn chị vẫn cố gắng tiết kiệm từng đồng nuôi các con ăn học. Vòng vốn này chị Tơ xin vay 575USD mua lợn con, thức ăn gia súc và nứa để đan thúng. Thu nhập hàng tháng của gia đình là 150USD.

loans.use: Buy piglets, mash for them and bamboo to weave baskets

loans.name: Sara Vda De

texts.es:
Doña Sara is 62 years old, her main income is her pension as a widow and a local store. Sara is a widow with one son who recently married and has a baby. They all live together in an “anticrético” (a contract where the debtor agrees to creditor enjoying the profit of the estate until the debt has been settled). At the present her son is working in Spain and his wife and baby are staying with Sara. For the last 10 years Sara has been receiving her pension as a widow and she has had her store for more than 2 years. Competition is fair but growing as trade is increasing in the region.

The present application for a loan is to purchase 2 items: Firstly plastic products (plastic china, tupperware, and bathtubs) and secondly the rest of the loan will be invested in gifts (glasses, plates, etc.) Sara has had four loans with the institution with a good record and this will be her fifth loan.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Sara es una señora de 62 años de edad, su ingreso principal es una renta de viuda, paralelamente cuenta con una tienda de barrio. Sara es viuda y solo tiene un hijo el cual recientemente se casó y tiene un bebe. La familia vive en un anticrético ocupando la misma casa. Actualmente su hijo se fue a trabajar a España y dejó a la esposa y el bebé con su mamá (Sara). Sara desde hace más de 10 años percibe su ingreso de viuda y tiene el negocio de la tienda desde hace mas de 2 años. La competencia es media pero va creciendo por estar aumentando el movimiento comercial en la zona.

La presente solicitud será invertida en la adquisición de 2 items: primero productos de plástico, (plastiloza, tapers y bañeras) y posteriormente, y hasta donde alcance, regalos varios (vasos, platos, etc.) Sara ya tuvo cuatro créditos en la institución con un buen promedio y se está refinanciando la quinta operación que es la actual.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise to increase sales at general store.

loans.name: Trabajadoras Tolimán (Grupo I) Group

texts.es:
Despite the many difficulties that the women of the communal bank “Las Trabajadoras Tolimán” have faced, they live with determination and smiles that enable them to keep working hard. Although the women have only been together as a group for less than two years, they are like family, because they all live in the same community: the San Gregorio neighborhood. From living as neighbors for so many years, they have learned to work together, organizing celebrations, events, birthdays, and even charitable giving to support their neediest neighbors. This spirit of togetherness has allowed them to transitional with ease into working together as a bank.

Most of the women have small grocery stores, selling basic food items as well as cleaning products and cooking utensils. A few women have businesses buying and selling corn, beans, and coffee. In the area of Atitlán where these women live, coffee is harvested in January, so they are at their busiest time selling their coffee. And to add to the variety of the group, there are a few women who weave huipiles, an intricately woven traditional blouse worn by Guatemalan women. They also weave dresses, skirts, and belts.

Nine of the nineteen women are asking for a loan of $2700, with which they will purchase products to restock their stores, such as eggs, sugar, salt, soap, and detergent. Others will invest in corn, beans, and coffee in bulk, which they will then sell to their communities. The rest will go towards colorful threads and fabric to make their weavings.

The dream of the women of Las Trabajadoras Tolimán is to provide as best they can for their children. They are overcoming their hardships and determined to provide an education for their children, in order that they can have a better future.

loans.use: To buy products for grocery store; To buy corn, coffee, and beans; To buy threads for weaving

loans.name: Mariana

texts.es:
Mariana realized a long time ago that the money her husband made was not enough to sustain their three children (8 years old, 2 years and a 9 month baby). Her friend turned her onto selling cosmetics. Mariana currently has her own client base.

She has various orders from her clients but she can´t purchase the goods. Mariana is requesting a US $925 microloan which she intends to return in six months. The money will be used to purchase merchandise for her clients. With your help Mariana will be able to raise her children.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Le Thi H., 33 years old, is the 5th member of the 14th branch of the Fund. She is living with her husband and 2 children in Quang Xuong town, Thanh H.. Besides working on her 5 rice fields (360 m2 / each field), her main activity is to weave sedge mat to increase the income and repay weekly. Mrs. H. uses the money borrowed from the Fund to buy more materials (jute, sedge) to weave mats. Her income from weaving mats is stable. Her family life is improved: they have better and more nutritious meals, their children are sent to school. The price for one sedge mat is 4-6 USD. Her current income is 120 USD/ month. This time, she wants to borrow 400 USD to buy more jute and sedge.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Lê Thị Hòa, 33 tuổi, thành viên năm thứ năm của chi nhánh 14, sống cùng chồng và 2 con nhỏ tại Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Ngoài làm 5 sào ruộng, công việc chủ yếu của gia đình chị là làm chiếu để tăng thu nhập và lấy tiền trả hàng tuần. Vốn vay từ Quỹ được chị Hòa sử dụng mua nguyên liệu (đay, cói) về dệt chiếu. Nguồn thu từ làm chiếu ổn định, kinh tế gia đình chị Hòa dần được nâng cao, chất các bữa ăn được bảo đảm, con cái được đi học đến nơi đến chốn. Giá một đôi chiếu từ 4-6USD, thu nhập hàng tháng của gia đình đạt 120USD. Vòng vốn tới chị xin vay mức vốn 400USD để mua thêm cói và đay.

loans.use: Buy sedge to weave mat

loans.name: Albina's Group

texts.en:
Albina, Ana and Alicia have been members of the community bank Golondrinas for one to two years each. In their community bank they have learned to be punctual and use their money more effectively. They mentioned that in their community bank they are able to forget their other problems.

Albina is 36 years old. She is married and has one son. Albina has owned a store where she sells food staples, such as flour sugar, vegetables and meat, for two years. She runs her store out of her home. In addition, Albina knits sweaters that she sells to her friends and family.

Ana is 24. She lives with her husband and two children. Ana, together with her husband, has a motorcycle taxi. They have owned the taxi for one year. Before this, Ana sold food from her home, but she decided to stop in order to spend more time with her children. She is planning to open a stationery store in her house.

Alicia is 58 years old. She is married and has eight children, six of whom live with her. Alicia started a store selling food staples in her house about one year ago. She was able to start her business with her first loan form the community bank.

Albina, Ana and Alicia need loans of 400, 600, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying sugar, rice, needles, milk, oil, firewood, and to start a new business, paper, notebooks, and pencils.

The community bank emphasizes the importance of saving and each associate has an interest-earning savings account. Albina, Ana, and Alicia plan to invest their savings in their businesses and for such uses as building a house and pay for a husband’s health care. Their dreams incluD. buying a car, opening an auto parts store, finishing the second floor of one of their homes, and seeing that their children will be professionals.

loans.use: To buy supplies for the three women's businesses

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mat-weaving is one common activity that brings stable income in Quang Xuong town, Thanh Hoa. However, weaving a pretty sedge mat is not easy for every family. Knowing the customers’ need and taste, Mrs. Nguyen Thi L., 43 years old, and her family, focus on weaving attractive mats. Therefore, the materials required need to be sophisticated. When materials are still cheap, she borrows money to buy good materials for mats. Then, she sells them with higher prices to the customers. All of her mats are welcomed and consumed by the customers. As a result, she can raise her 3 children and send them to school. Her family life is also much better. Her current income is 200 USD/ month. This time, she wants to borrow 400 USD to buy more sedge and other materials. She is currently a member of the 14th branch of the Fund.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Làm chiếu là một nghề mang lại thu nhập ổn định và rất phổ biến tại huyện Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa, nhưng làm chiếu đẹp thì không phải gia đình nào cũng làm được. Nắm bắt được nhu cầu của thị trường, gia đình chị Nguyễn Thị Lâm, 43 tuổi, tập trung làm chiếu đẹp, vì vậy yêu cầu của nguyên liệu cũng cầu kỳ. Khi giá cả đang rẻ chị vay vốn mua nguyên liệu tốt để làm chiếu. Khi gặp khách chị bán lại với giá cao. Chiếu chị dệt ra bao nhiêu tiêu thụ hết bằng ấy. Nhờ vậy chị Lâm có thể nuôi 3 con ăn học tới nơi tới chốn, cuộc sống gia đình cũng đầy đủ. Thu nhập hàng tháng khoảng 200USD, vòng vốn tới chị xin vay thêm 400USD để mua đay, cói làm chiếu. Chị Lâm hiện đang là thành viên của chi nhánh 14.

loans.use: Buy sedge to weave mat

loans.name: Vu Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Vu Thi L., 52 years old, is a member of the 14th branch of the Fund. She is living mainly as a fishmonger. This activity is very common in the coastal area. Usually, her husband and son will go fishing offshore, and she and her daughter will stay at home to sell the fish. Her children are all grown-up and become main workers of the house. Her income from fishing and fish mongering is pretty decent. However, her business will run better if she has better tools. She talked to her family and decided to borrow 400 USD to buy more fishing tools so that her fishing business will be more effective. Her current income is 250-270 USD/month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Vũ Thị Liễn, 52 tuổi, thành viên chi nhánh 14 sinh sống chủ yếu bằng nghề buôn bán cá. Đây là nghề phổ biến với người dân vùng biển. Thông thường, chồng và con trai trong nhà sẽ ra biển đánh cá, vợ và con gái sơ chế và bán cá. Các con chị Liễn đều đã lớn và trở thành những lao động thực sự trong gia đình. Thu nhập từ việc đánh bắt cũng khá cao, nhưng cũng cần có đồ nghề tốt thì công việc mới tiến triển thuận lợi. Chị bàn bạc với gia đình và xin vay 400USD sắm thêm đồ nghề để việc đánh bắt mang lại hiệu quả cao nhất. Thu nhập hiện tại của gia đình chị Liễn là 250-270USD/tháng.

loans.use: Buy fishing-net, catching tools

loans.name: Trabajadoras Tolimán (Grupo Ii) Group

texts.es:
The communal bank “Las Trabajadoras Tolimán” really is enchanting. In spite of the difficulties of life that an indigenous woman lives day to day, these ladies have a smile stamped on their faces that would encourage anyone to forge ahead. The ladies are a very solid and serious group, considering that they have only been together for two cycles. This is due largely to the fact that that they all live together in the same community: the San Gregorio neighborhood. In this neighborhood they live together everyday, organizing celebrations, religious events, birthdays, and charitable giving to support their neediest neighbors.

The “Trabajadoras Tolimán” are also a relatively homogeneous group, in that all of the women are requesting almost the same loan, between $260.00 and $390.00. This reflects the fact that the clients are advancing at an even pace in respect to entrepreneurial development.

The majority of the women have small grocery stores where they sell kitchen items and clearing products, among other products. Others have businesses buying and selling corn, beans, and coffee. It is important to explain that coffee is harvested in the Atitlán region of Guatemala during the month of January; therefore, the coffee business is at its peak right now. Another group of them weaves huipiles, the traditional clothing for Guatemalan women, and dresses, skirts, and belts.

The ladies are going to use the loan to buy products for the home, such as: eggs, sugar, salt, soap, detergent, etc. Others will use it to buy corn, beans, and coffee in bulk in the fields where they are harvested, so that they can later sell them back in their communities. The rest will use the loan to buy threads and fabric to make their weavings.

Many of the women dream of providing the best for their children and this is a big challenge. Among them is a widow who is the mother of ten children. She told me that she was only able to help her children get ahead in life through working very hard everyday. Her story really makes an impact.

It is imperative that these women recieve their next loan so that their business can succeed. Give the “Trabajadoras de Tolimán” a helping hand so that they can achieve their dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

El banco comunal Las Trabajadoras Tolimán es realmente encantador. A pesar de las durezas de la vida que una mujer indígena vive durante el día a día, estas señoras tienen una sonrisa estampada en la cara que alienta a cualquiera a seguir adelante. Las señoras conforman un grupo consolidado y muy serio, teniendo en cuenta que sólo han estado juntas dos ciclos. Esto se debe en mayor parte, a que todas viven en la misma comunidad: la colonia San Gregorio. En esta colonia ellas conviven diariamente organizando fiestas, eventos religiosos, cumpleaños, festividades y pequeñas colectas para apoyar a los vecinos más necesitados.

Las Trabajadoras Tolimán también son un grupo relativamente homogéneo, ya que todas las señoras están pidiendo casi el mismo préstamo entre US$260 y US$390. Esto refleja que las clientas están avanzando a un ritmo parejo en lo que respecta desarrollo empresarial.

La gran mayoría de señoras ya tienen una tienda de consumo diario, donde ellas venden artículos de cocina, de limpieza, entre otros productos. Otras tienen un negocio de compra y venta de maíz, fríjol y café. Es importante destacar que durante el mes de enero el café es cosechado en la región de Atitlán en Guatemala, por ende el negocio cafetero está en auge en estos momentos. Mientras que otro grupo trabaja tejiendo huipiles, trajes tradicionales Guatemalatecos para las mujeres, cortes o faldas y fajas.

Las señoras van a utilizar su préstamo para comprar productos para la casa como: huevos, azúcar, sal, jabón, detergente, etc. Otras van a utilizarlo para comprar maíz, fríjol y café al por mayor en los campos de cosecha, para luego revenderlo en sus comunidades. Mientras que el resto lo va a utilizar para comprar hilos y telas para elaborar sus tejidos.

Muchas de estas señoras sueñan con brindar lo mejor a sus hijos y eso es un gran reto. Entre ellas hay una madre viuda que trajo al mundo a diez hijos. Ella me contó que solo luchando y trabajando podía sacar adelante a sus hijos. Una historia realmente impresionante.

Es imperativo que estas señoras reciban su siguiente préstamo para que así su negocio pueda salir adelante. Brinden a las Trabajadoras de Tolimán una mano para que así ellas puedan lograr sus sueños.

loans.use: To buy products for the home; to buy corn, beans, and coffee; to buy threads

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.es:
Consuelo was retired, but she decided to start a business because she did not like being idle at home. Her husband´s income as a mechanic is also insufficient to pay for their home expenses. So she began making handicrafts, jewellry, and selling catalog goods. Slowly but surely she built up her client base.

Consuelo has to purchase more merchandise. On the photograph we see her with a picture in her hand and a small bracelet as this is the only way to display what she sells until she gets more stock. Consuelo needs a US $925 microloan to repay in 6 months. With this money she will purchase more merchandise to increase her sales. With your help Consuelo will be able to make her business flourish.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.<

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Adela

texts.es:
From a young age, Adela dreamed of having her own business. She purchased a copying machine at first and slowly added merchandise to her store. Shortly after starting the office supplies store she married and had children but she is now a single mom. Her store is the only income for her and her children.

Adela needs to grow her business which is why she is requesting a US $200 microloan to return in 3 months. With this money, Adela will be able purchase paper, pens, notebooks and other merchandise for her stationary. Your help will give Adela the money she needs to raise her children on her own.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.<

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Angelica

texts.es:
Angelica is a 53 year old woman. She has been buying and selling potatoes and its derived products such as “chuño” and “tunta” in the fair of Villa Remedios, Layuri, for the past 12 years with the help of her husband. She has been living with her family in the community of Kella Kella in the Murillo province for the past 38 years. Although there is competition in her business, Angelica provides a good service to her clients and she is very responsible when attending her stand, which is located in the main square. She will use the loan to buy wholesale merchandise which she will later on sell. Angelica has no negative record in the financial system and she is very responsible with the payment of her quotas.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer.

Angelica es una señora de 53 años que se dedica a la compra y venta de papa, chuño y tunta, estos productos los comercializa en las ferias de Villa Remedios, Layuri desde hace más de 12 años junto a su esposo. Actualmente vive con su familia en la comunidad de Kella Kella en la provincia Murillo desde hace 38 años. Si bien existe competencia en el mercado, Angelica da un buen trato a sus clientes y también tiene bastante responsabilidad al momento de atender su puesto de venta, el mismo se encuentra ubicado en plena plaza principal. El crédito será destinado para la adquisición de mercadería al por mayor parasu posterior comercialización. Angelica no tiene antecedentes negativos en el sistema financiero y es una persona muy responsable con el cumplimiento de sus cuotas.

loans.use: To buy wholesale merchandise

loans.name: Vidalina's Group

texts.en:
Vidalina, Ruth, and Delia are members of the community bank Inti. Vidalina has been a member for 13 years, while Ruth and Delia joined two and three years ago. In that time they have learned the importance of responsibility and punctuality. They have also learned how to manage the ups and downs of owning a business.

Vidalina is 70 years old and has 12 adult children. She and her husband own a business selling wood products. They sell some construction materials, and also make and sell furniture. At the moment they are working to design new varieties and styles of furniture. She has been running this business for 53 years, and the entire family helps. In addition, Vidalina owns a small store where she sells food staples such as flour, eggs, sugar, and milk.

Ruth is 41 and has two children. She has been selling vegetables at the local market in the city of Ayacucho for many years. She is able to receive a good price by buying vegetables in bulk every morning and then selling them during the day.

Delia is 46 and has three children. She has owned a juice stand for six years. She sells a large variety of fresh fruit juices at the Nery Garcia market in Ayacucho. Her husband was in an accident and can no longer work, so Delia is the sole provider for the family.

Vidalina, Ruth, and Delia need loans of 1600, 400, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying wood, nails, paint, carrots, lettuce, tomatoes, fruits, and sugar. One of the attractive things about the community bank is that each associate has an interest-earning savings account. Vidalina, Ruth, and Delia are saving to be able to pay for any emergency that should arise. They all said that having the savings account gives them a sense of security that they did not have before. Their dreams are to continue working and continue improving their lives.

loans.use: For the three women to buy wood, nails, paint, carrots, lettuce, tomatoes, fruits, and sugar for their businesses

loans.name: Cristobal

texts.es:
Don Cristóbal is 40 years old and as a living he extracts sand and his wife sells clothing, shoes and course material. There are 7 members in Cristobal’s family; his children study and live with their parents who have their own house. The mother sells her merchandise in a village far from Yapacaní and she is at home Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday, while Cristobal works all week with his dump truck extracting sand which activity he has carried out for several years.

Cristobal competes with several individuals who extract sand, but his insistence and dedication to his work has made him well-known and popular in the area. With this application his wife will buy pencils, pens, notebooks, binder sheets, bond paper, erasers, etc. to be sold before school starts. This is Cristobal’s fourth application with our institution and he has always been a responsible and punctual payer of his installments.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Don Cristobal es un señor de 40 años de edad que se dedica a la extracción de áridos y su esposa a la venta de ropa, zapatos y material escolar. La familia de Cristobal consta de 7 miembros, sus hijos estudian y viven junto a sus padres en casa propia. La mamá lleva la mercadería a un pueblo lejano de Yapacaní para poder comercializarla y sólo se la encuentra en su casa los días martes, miércoles y jueves, mientras Cristobal trabaja toda la semana con su volqueta extrayendo áridos, esta actividad la desarrolla desde hace varios años atrás.

Cristobal compite con varias personas que se dedican a la extracción de arena, pero el empeño y dedicación de su trabajo hacen que sea muy conocido y solicitado en la zona. Con la presente solicitud la esposa comprará lápices, bolígrafos, cuadernos, hojas de carpeta, hojas de papel bond, borradores, etc. para poder comercializar los mismos antes de que empiecen las clases. Esta solicitud es la cuarta de Cristobal en nuestra institución, donde demostró ser una persona responsable y puntual en el pago de sus cuotas.

loans.use: Purchase material for stationer's to increase sales.

loans.name: José Vianey

texts.es:
Vianey started selling flowers so that she could help her husband with the household expenses. That business required a lot of investment, and for this reason she was forced to change businesses and started selling clothing three years ago. Now she sells clothes in the traveling markets. Vianey's dream is to build a small store outside her house and also to have a stall in a stationary market.

For this reason Vianey is asking for a loan of $650 that she is ready to repay over a period of 6 months. With this money she will be able to buy more clothing and expand her business little by little. This way she can establish a store in her home. With your help Vianey would be able to help her family get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Vianey comenzó a vender flores para poder ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos de la casa. Sin embargo este negocio requería de mucha inversión, fue por eso que se vio obligada a cambiar de giro fue así como encontró la venta de ropa hace tres años, actualmente vende en los mercados rodantes sin embargo el sueño de Vianey es poder hacer un pequeño local fuera de su casa, además de tener un local en un mercado fijo.

Es por eso que Vianey está solicitando un crédito de US $650 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero podrá comprar más ropa para ir creciendo poco a poco y así poder establecerse en un local en su casa. Con tu ayuda Vianey podrá sacar adelante a su familia.

loans.use: Purchase clothing

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa has been a member of the community bank Inti for five years. She was encouraged to join the bank by a cousin who is also a member. As part of a community bank Luisa has learned how to save, how to be responsible and punctual, and the importance of sending her children to school. She has also been the fiscal officer for her bank several times.

Luisa is 38 years old and has four children between the ages of 18 and three. She and her husband own a business selling fireworks, which he makes. They have been running this business for 15 years. In addition, Luisa has a store where she sells food staples, such as flour, sugar, and milk.

Luisa needs a loan of 2400 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will invest in buying chemicals from Lima and additional products for her store.

Each associate has an interest-earning savings account at the community bank. For most, this is the first time they have been able to open an account. Luisa plans to use her savings to build a house on a piece of land that she has already bought. Her dream is to finish her house and see her children become professionals.

loans.use: To buy chemicals to make fireworks and buy additional products for her store

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
Martha, 43 years old, is the single mother of a 12-year old daughter in the sixth grade and a 13-year old son in his first year of secondary school. Her humble home is constructed in its entirety out of zinc metal. Given that her neighborhood is not in an urban area, water overflow from the streets runs freely into her small house.

This mother lives alone with her two children. She leaves for work very early in the morning, earning a small income as a cook at a restaurant. Martha wishes to start rehabbing her house so she can provide better living conditions for her children, as well as a safer, more peaceful home environment for them.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Martha tiene 43 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene 2 hijos, una niña de 12 años de edad que se encuentra cursando 6to grado de primaria y un varón de 13 años que se encuentra en 1 año de secundaria, su humilde vivienda esta construida toda de latas de zinc, las calles no están urbanizadas, es por eso que las aguas residuales que corren por las calles se le mete a su pequeña vivienda. Esta madre vive sola con sus 2 hijos pequeños, ella sale a trabajar desde muy temprano, se desempeña como cocinera de un restaurante y los ingresos son bajos. En estos momentos Doña Martha desea iniciar la reconstrucción de su vivienda, con el objetivo de darles a sus pequeños hijos mejores condiciones de vida, seguridad y tranquilidad.

loans.use: Build a concrete wall in her home.

loans.name: Aquilina Agustina's Group

texts.en:
Felicitas, Carmen, and Aquilina are members of the community bank Alianza. Felicitas and Carmen have both been members for 12 years, while Aquilina joined two years ago. In that time they have learned how to save (which they were unable to do previously), the importance of being punctual, and how to work efficiently.

Felicitas is 48 and has four children, only one of whom still lives with her. She sells cuchinilla, which are small insects used to make red dyes. Felicitas has been doing this all of her life. She buys the insects from the countryside and sells them in the city of Ayacucho. She has been able to help two of her children graduate from university. Her oldest is now working as a pharmacist.

Carmen is 43 and has five children between the ages of 23 and 7. She is an artisan. She weaves beautiful blankets and wall hangings that she sells in the local market of Ayacucho. Carmen was taught by her mother and has been weaving all her life.

Aquilina is 50 and has eleven children between the ages of 40 and 27. Two times per week Aquilina travels eight hours each way to the jungle to buy fruits, vegetables, and grains, which she then sells in Ayacucho. Aquilina started helping her mom in the same business when she was a young girl and now continues on her own.

Felicitas, Carmen, and Aquilina need loans of 1000, 800, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in their businesses by buying cuchinilla, fruits, vegetables, grains, thread, and dyes.

One of the important things about the community bank is that each associate has an interest-earning savings account. Felicitas, Carmen, and Aquilina plan to use their savings to pay for their children’s schooling and improve their homes. Their dreams are to be able to afford nice things and modern conveniences in their homes, and to see their children become professionals.

loans.use: For the three women to buy cuchinilla, fruits, vegetables, grains, thread, and dyes

loans.name: Publia's Group

texts.en:
Publia, Yeni, and Neri are members of the community bank Alianza. Publia and Neri have been members for three years, while Yeni joined one year ago. In that time they have learned how to improve their businesses, save, and be responsible. In addition, they all agreed that the community bank has helped them to become more independent. The responsibility of handling money has improved their self-esteem and taught them that they are intelligent and capable. Having their own money gives them the strength to stand up to their husbands and be more active in making decisions concerning the family.

Publia is 40 and has three young children. She moved to Ayacucho from Lima seven years ago, and several people recommended that she join the community bank. Eventually, she decided to attend a meeting and then to become a member. Publia sells auto parts. She has been running her store in Ayacucho for seven years, and ran one in Lima for three years before that.

Yeni is 21 years old and just had her third child two months ago. Publia is a friend of hers and convinced her to join the community bank. She sells shish kabob from a cart at various locations in the city of Ayacucho. She has been running this business for six years.

Neri is 36 years old and expecting her first child. She joined the bank three years ago to help pay for university studies. She has been selling fashionable clothing for seven years. Customers in Ayacucho order what they like and then Neri travels ten hours to Lima three times each month to buy the orders.

Publia, Yeni, and Neri need loans of 1600, 600, and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in buying a larger selection of auto parts, meat, oil, salt, and clothing.

Each member of the community bank has an interest-earning savings account. Publia plans to use her savings to travel to see her family in the city of Arequipa. It will be the first time she has seen them in two years. Yeni is saving to send her children to school, and Neri plans to use her savings to buy all of the things her new baby will need. Their dreams are to improve their homes and have healthy families. In addition, Neri hopes to earn her master's degree in environmental science.

loans.use: For the three women to buy a larger selection of auto parts, meat, oil, salt, and clothing for their businesses

loans.name: Casilda

texts.es:
Doña Casilda is 49 years old and for a living she sells vegetables at the market “Primero de Abril” seven days a week. Casilda has four children and her husband is a small farmer. On the other hand, three of her daughters are employees and with their income they buy their own clothes for the beginning of the school year as their mother does not earn enough. They own a house at the km. 21, El Palmar, a wooden house with 2 rooms.

Casilda has been selling vegetables at the market for the past four years, before that she sold second-hand garments, but the sale of vegetables is more profitable as she can also use them to feed her family. Her stand is small and she has to compete with several saleswomen offering the same products and with bigger stands. The success of her business is because of her persistence and responsibility to attract clients. With the present loan she will buy 18 “arrobas” (1 arroba = 25 pounds) of big potatoes at Bs.(Bolivianos) 560.-, 9 “arrobas” of small potatoes at Bs. 200.-, a bag of onions at Bs. 140.-, a box of tomatoes at Bs. 60.-, other kinds of vegetables Bs. 78.-. She will give part of the loan, Bs.150.-, to her husband to buy pesticide for his rice and the rest will be used to pay basic necessities such as electricity and water. This is Casilda’s third transaction with this institution and she has had few late payments.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Casilda es una señora de 49 de edad que se dedica al comercio de verduras en el mercado PRIMERO DE ABRIL, donde atiende todos los días. Casilda tiene cuatro hijos y su esposo es un pequeño agricultor. Por otra parte tres de sus hijas trabajan como empleadas para poder comprarse ropa para el inicio de clases ya que a su madre no le alcanza. Viven en una casa propia en el km. 21, El Palmar, en una casa de madera de 2 ambientes.

Casilda vende verduras en el mercado desde hace cuatro años atrás, anteriormente vendía ropa usada pero ella considera que la venta de la verdura es mejor ya que con ello puede alimentar a su familia, su puesto es pequeño y ahí debe competir con varias vendedoras que ofrecen los mismos productos y con puestos más grandes. El éxito de su negocio es la persistencia y responsabilidad para atraer clientela. Con la presente solicitud comprará 18 arrobas de papa grande a Bs. 560.-, 9 arrobas de papa pequeña Bs. 200.-, Una bolsa de cabezas de cebollas Bs. 140.-, Una caja de tomate Bs. 60.-, Otras especies Bs. 78.-.Después una parte le dará a su esposo para que compre veneno para su arroz Bs.150.- y el resto para el pago de luz, agua y otras necesidades básicas. Esta es la tercera operación de Casilda en la institución, tiempo en el cuál mantuvo una mora muy baja.

loans.use: Purchase vegetables to increase sales at market place.

loans.name: Lenin Augusto

texts.es:
Lenin is 23 years old and is married with two sons ages four and one. He works as a team supervisor at an electrical company. His house is constructed out of two different materials: half concrete, half lumber. In his desire to advance, he has decided to seek financing to rebuild his home. With the loan, he will build the walls of his living room out of concrete. His wish is to provide his small children with a more decent life.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Lenin L. tiene 23 años de edad, casada, y con 2 hijos varones de 4 años y un año respectivamente. Trabaja como Supervisor de Brigada de una empresa de electricidad. Su casa de habitación es minifalda, mitad de concreto y mitad de tabla. En su afan por buscar la prosperidad, decidió buscar financiamiento pra empezar la reconstrucción de su casa, con el crédito va a construir los muros de la sala de habitación de concreto. Quiere darle una vida más digna a sus pequeños niños.

loans.use: Build concrete walls for living room.

loans.name: Fatima Lissette

texts.es:
The sale of liquid gas is the business to which Fatima P. devotes much effort, in the area around the market at the city of Leon´s bus station.

Because she is a married mother with two school-age children, she decided to start up this business in order to improve her standard of living and provide her children with a mother´s love by means of food and a roof over their head. Mrs. P.´s current need is to acquire cylinders of gas, for which she turns to Ceprodel so she can receive the benefit of loans which she invests in the purchase of her products. She has a record of 4 loans with Ceprodel.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La venta de gas licuado es el negocio al que con mucho esfuerzo se dedica la señora Fatima P. en las inmediaciones del mercado La Terminal de la ciudad de León.

Por ser madre casada y con dos hijos en edad escolar decide emprender este negocio para mejorar sus situación de vida y brindarle a sus hijos el calor de madre por medio de la alimentación y el techo digno. La necesidad actual de la señora P. es la adquisición de los cilindros de gas por lo que acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con los créditos que los invierte en la adquisición de sus productos. Su record es de 4 créditos con Ceprodel.

loans.use: Purchase cylinders of gas.

loans.name: Fredy

texts.es:
In my house I have a store where I sell Omnilife products. I have a long list of customers and now I would like to sell my products in some nearby towns. I would also like to sell to ranches but for this I need to invest in the purchase of more merchandise in order to offer my clients a greater variety of products. I am asking for a loan of $500 to invest in my business.

Translated from Spanish by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer

Tengo en mi casa una venta D. productos Omnilife y ya tengo una lista granD. D. clientes, ahora me gustaría venderr mis productos en algunos puebL. que están cerca, también en rancherías pero para eso necesito invertir en la compra D. más mercancía y poder ofrecerles a mis clientes productos variados”. Solicito $ 500.00 dlls para invertir en mi negocio.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of merchandise for my business

loans.name: Maria Nubia

texts.es:
For the past 14 years, in the city of León in the market at the bus station, María U. has sold clothing of all sizes and for all age groups. She has her own section, which has cost her a sizeable investment, and because she is a married mother with small children to support, she has managed to supply greater quantities of clothing for her business.

She started the business 14 years ago, walking through the market, exposed to the sun and to physical exhaustion from walking so much. Little by little she began to save so she could pay for an area inside the market until she finally got it.

Since she was able to get the section in the market, she has had 12 loans with Ceprodel, which have had a great impact on her because of the fact that she has bought greater quantities of clothing to offer and, in addition, has been able to sustain her home.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

Desde hace 14 años en la ciudad de Leon en el mercado La Terminal, la señora Maria U. se dedica a la venta de ropa de todos tamaños y para todas las edades. Posee un tramo propio el cual le ha costado mucha inversión y por ser una madre casada y con hijos pequeños a que mantener ha logrado surtir de mayores cantidades de ropa su negocio.

El negocio lo comienza hace 14 años vendiendo ambulante en todo el mercado, exponiéndose al sol y al desgaste físico de producidos por el caminar mucho. Poco a poco comenzó a invertir para pagar un local interno en el mercado hasta que lo obtuvo.

Desde que logró obtener el tramo en el mercado, ha realizado 12 créditos en Ceprodel que le han impactado grandemente por el hecho de que ha comprado mayores volúmenes de ropa para ofrecer y además ha podido sostener el núcleo de su hogar.

loans.use: Purchase clothing.

loans.name: María Del Rosario

texts.es:
Because her two children are married, María del Rosario and her husband separated. For this reason she started her own business selling used clothing and can thus support herself. María sells the clothing in front of her house and little by little she is becoming well-known in the business.

María needs seasonal merchandise to offer to her clients. Mariá del Rosario is asking for a loan of $925 that she is prepared to repay over a period of 6 months. With this money María will be able to buy more clothing, such as shirts, pants, dresses and other articles. With your help María will be able to help her family get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Ya que sus dos hijos se casaron, María del Rosario se separó de su esposo, fue por eso que comenzó su propio negocio de venta de ropa usada y así poderse mantener sola. María vende la ropa fuera de su casa y poco a poco se ha ido haciendo conocida.

María necesita mercancía de la temporada para poder ofrecerle a sus clientes. María del Rosario está solicitando un crédito de US $925 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero María podrá comprar más ropa, como blusas, pantalones, vestidos, entre otras cosas. Con tu ayuda María podrá sacar adelante a su familia.

loans.use: Purchase a bundle of clothing

loans.name: Rosalva

texts.es:
It has been 10 years since Rosalva began to sell catalog cosmetics after her daughter was born, because she wanted to be able to care for her. Bit by bit she began to acquire a larger variety of products and now she sells various brands. However the fight continues for clients. Due to the fact that Rosalva wishes her business would grow she is requesting a loan of $375 USD that is arranged to be paid in a term of 4 months and with this money she will purchase more merchandise so that she can have a variety for her clients. With your help Rosalva will be able to better her family.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Hace 10 años que Rosalva comenzó a vender cosméticos por catálogo después de que su hija nació, puesto que no quería descuidarla mucho. Poco a poco ha ido adquiriendo más variedad en sus productos y ahora vende de varias marcas. Sin embargo la lucha continúa por los clientes.

Y debido a que Rosalva desea que su negocio crezca es por lo que está solicitando un crédito de US $375 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 4 meses y con este dinero podrá comprar más mercancía para poder tener variedad para sus clientes. Con tu ayuda Rosalva podrá sacar adelante a su hija.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Ana Clemencia

texts.es:
For the past 20 years, Ana Clemencia has been selling food at the market in the bus terminal of León. The main dish she makes is nacatamales, (Nicaraguan tamales, usually combining ingredients such as raisins, capers, and green olives and wrapped in banana leaves), which she distributes at different points in the market for delivery to her customers. At the same time, other customers arrive at her stand and buy food to go.

She is a single mother and the only support for her family. Over time, she decided to ask for loans from CEPRODEL, which have not been denied her but have been granted so she can buy ingredients with which to make food and her delicious nacatamales. Her greatest need is that she urgently needs to buy ingredients.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Ana Clemencia se dedica desde hace 20 años a la actividad de venta de comida en el mercado la Terminal de León. Su actividad consiste en elaborar los alimentos siendo su principal platillo los nacatamales y luego distribuirlos en diferentes puntos del mercado hasta entregarlo a sus clientes. De igual manera, otros clientes llegan hacia su puesto y compran los alimentos para llevarlos.

Es madre soltera y es el único sustento de su hogar. En el transcurso del tiempo decide solicitar créditos en CEPRODEL, los que no le han sido negados sino que le han sido otorgados para la compra de su materia prima para la elaboración de sus alimentos y sus deliciosos nacatamales. Su mayor necesidad radica en que urgentemente necesita adquirir la materia prima.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make food.

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.es:
On the patio of my house I began the construction of a room, but I could not complete it due to lack of funds. I would like to set up slabs of concrete and seal the walls well so that the room is hospitable. In this season of rain and cold there is a lot of humidity, and this causes my family to get sick. I request a loan of $1,000 so that I can finish building this room in my home.

 Translated by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer 

En el patio de mi casa empecé la construcción de un cuarto pero ya no lo pude terminar por falta de dinero, me gustaría poner una losa de concreto y cerrar bien las paredes para poder habitarlo ya que ahora en tiempo de frio y de lluvia hay mucha humedad y esta provoca enfermedades a mi familia”. Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para terminar la construcción de un cuarto en mi vivienda.

loans.use: To finish the construction of a room in my home

loans.name: Ignacia Yolanda

texts.es:
Ignacia R. sells groceries such as oil, soap, pastas, detergents, brooms, shampoo, etc. She started her business 10 years ago in the market at the León bus station, with a small investment that she borrowed from a moneylender. Once she bought the first products, she worked hard to sell them and looked for a way to get out of debt and finish paying it off.

One of her needs is to invest in the purchase of groceries, and for this reason she has approached Ceprodel for loans (she has had 5 loans), which she invests directly in her business, and in this way she supports her home, which needs it so much.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Ignacia R. se dedica a vender productos de abarrotaría como aceite, jabón, pastas, detergentes, escobas, shampoo, etc.) Su negocio da inicio desde hace 10 años en el mercado la Terminal de León, con una pequeña inversión que los obtuvo por medio de un préstamo a un prestamista. Una vez que compró los primeros productos, muy esforzadamente los comercializó y busco la manera de cómo salir de esta deuda hasta acabarla.

Una necesidad que posee esta dama es que necesita invertir en la compra de los abarrotes y por esta razón es que acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con créditos (Actualmente 5 créditos a su favor) que los invierte directamente en su negocio y de esta manera llevar el sustento a su hogar que tanto lo necesita.

loans.use: Purchase products.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
After separating from her husband, Julia began to sell food in her house, thanks to the good flavor of her tamales, Julia was able to grow her business bit by bit and relocate it to a small location outside a factory, which gives her many clients at lunchtime. However, Julia realizes that her business needs other products. Because of this she requests a loan of $475 USD that is arranged to be paid in one term of 6 months and with this money Julia will be able to buy more merchandise so that she can produce other types of food and her clients can eat other things. With your help Julia will be able to succeed and be happy.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Después de que se separó de su esposo, Julia comenzó a vender comidas en su casa, gracias al buen sabor de sus tamales, Julia pudo crecer un poco su negocio y poder poner un localito fuera de una fábrica, lo cual le deja más clientes, puesto que a la hora de comida salen a comprarle. Sin embargo Julia considera que su negocio necesita otros productos.

Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $475 que está dispuesta a pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Julia podrá comprar más mercancía para poder elaborar otro tipo de comidas y así sus clientes coman otras cosas. Con tu ayuda Julia podrá salir adelante y luchar por su felicidad.

loans.use: To buy merchandise to produce food

loans.name: Jose Celedonio

texts.es:
The business that José Celedonios works at is carpentry, which he has developed over the past 10 years with much sacrifice. His business is located in the market at the bus station in León. Since he was young he has had experience in this type of work, as he was in a carpentry workshop for many years. He tells us that this business has been the only means of support for him and his family. In addition, because of the business, his daughter is able to study.

One of Jose´s greatest achievements has been that he has been able to capture a number of clients in the area, owing to the fact that his carpentry work is of high quality and very professional. For the past year he has worked with CEPRODEL and he is very satisfied with the loans granted to him, as they have been made at opportune moments, helping him to supply the needs of his workshop. In this way he has been able to fulfill requests from his clients and continue to pay for his daughter´s studies.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio al que se dedica el señor José Celedonio es la carpintería que con mucho sacrificio ha venido desarrollando desde hace 10 años en la ciudad de León en el mercado la Estación. Desde muy pequeño ha tenido experiencia en lo que respecta a este trabajo, ya que por muchísimo tiempo trabajó en un taller y nos cuenta que este negocio ha sido el único sustento para el y su familia. Además por medio del negocio beneficia a su hija que es estudiante.

Un merito muy grande que ha tenido el señor José es que ha logrado captar varios clientes en su zona debido a que los trabajos de carpintería los realiza muy finamente y con alta profesionalidad. Trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace un año y se siente muy satisfecho con los créditos otorgados pues se los han brindados en el momento oportuno, ayudando a sí a suplir las necesidades del taller y de esta manera poder satisfacer los pedidos de los clientes y seguir manteniendo los estudios de su hija.

loans.use: Purchase equipment and wood.

loans.name: Sarmani

texts.en: Sarmani, 39, has a small shop in front of her house where she sells fried snacks, ice, etc., and earns about $8 a day. Her husband, A., works as a landless farmer who has irregular income.
