Annet is 40 years old and is single. She has 6 children ranging from age 10 to 22 and her children go to school. Each week, Annet makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a new house. Annet is joined in her small group by Prossy K., Christine T., Betty N., and Margret Nakkazi.

Prossy K. is currently in the restaurant business and is requesting a loan of UGX 1000000 to buy more kitchen utensils. Christine T. is currently in the beauty salon business and is requesting a loan of UGX 300000 to buy a hair steamer. Betty N. is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan of UGX 1000000 to increase her stock. Margret Nakkazi is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan of UGX 300000 to buy more land for quarrying stones.

loans.use: To purchase more food for sale

loans.name: Mulago A(I) Group

Joyce is 32 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging from age 9 to 21, and her children go to school. Each week, Joyce makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children.

Joyce is joined in her small group by Cissy Nakabuuye, Milly N., Nalongo N., and Christine N.. Cissy Nakabuuye is currently in the retail business and is requesting a loan of UGX 400000 to increase stock. loans.name: Farid

texts.en: Mr. Farid, 25 years of age, is a vulnerable, low-income person. He is married and lives in the village of Saatli town located in the south-central flat area of Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus region. Farid and his wife run a family business together where he sells beef in the Saatli town while his wife grazes cattle. The income from four cows they own is too low to support the family. Therefore, Farid has applied to the Norwegian Microcredit Saatli branch for a $600 loan to buy calves in order to make his monthly income higher. In the Caucasus region, the price of a good calf is 250 USD.

loans.use: To buy calves

Each week, Prossy makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her retail business.

Prossy is joined in her small group by Rose N., Rose N., Natalia N., and Gertrude N.. Rose N. is currently in the business of selling used clothes and is requesting a loan of UGX 500000 to increase stock. loans.name: Nam-Minh Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nam, 31 years old, is married with two children. She farms a dozen pigs and a flock of poultry. Her family had taken out loan before from a agricultural bank in Yên Phong. That loan was for her husband to invest in his construction project. She is a group leader of a 2-persons group that Mr. Minh is the other member, whose wife has the same activity. They both would like to take out a loan to buy feed for their live stock and more piglets.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Nam 31 tuổi, chị có chồng và 2 con. Chị chăn nuôi lợn, và gà công nghiệp. Trước kia gia đình chị cũng tham gia vay vốn của Ngân hàng nông nghiệp huyện Yên Phong, tuy nhiên không phải dùng vào mục đích chăn nuôi mà cho chồng chị cai xây dựng. Chị tham gia vốn tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì chị thích hình thức trả dần. Chị vay về mua cám nuôi lợn vì trong chuồng nhà chị có trên chục con lợn thịt. Cùng nhóm với chị là anh Minh anh cũng tham gia vay vốn để mua lợn giống vì vợ anh chăn rất nhiều lợn. Tiền công đi làm của anh sẽ dành dụm để trả nợ.

loans.use: Buy feed for pigs and more piglets.

loans.name: Thi Mao

texts.vi:
Mrs. Mão, 27 years old, a hard working woman, is married with two children. She is in scrap material business. Everyday she rides her old bicycle more than ten kilometers around rural area to collect scrap then sells them back to the depots. She will use funds from the loan as capital money. She makes about 3USD a day. Not much but she can make the repayments.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Mão 27 tuổi, chị là người phụ nữ chịu khó. Chị đã có chồng và 2 con. Chị làm nghề đi mua phế liệu, hàng ngày chị đi chợ bằng chiếc xe đạp đã cũ, trên đường về chị bán lại hàng cho các đại lý thu mua. Chị vay vốn về để đi chợ thu gom được nhiều phế liệu hơn. Công việc của chị khá vất vả vì mỗi ngày chị đi xe đạp vài chục cây số. Thu nhập mỗi ngày của chị cũng được trên 50.000đ. Khoản thu này không lớn nhưng giúp chị có thể trả hàng tuần hợp lý.

loans.use: Buy scrap material

loans.name: Parvina

texts.ru:
Parvina was born in 1985, is single and lives with her parents. Her family is of average means. Her parents do not have money to pay for higher education, so after high school Parvina and her elder sister started working at a bakery that made pirozhki - baked or fried pastries/patties with meat or vegetable filling. There were three other young women working at the bakery.

Parvina worked at the bakery from 2002 to 2005. During this time she became very good at making pirozhki and decided to open up her own business. For the last three years she has successfully run such a business. She and her sister make the dough, her younger brother bakes and then sells the pirozhki. Her food stand is located in the 'Safariyon' Market and is definitely one of the well known ones.

Parvina joined MLF MicroInvest in early 2007 and has had good credit standing. When she found out about the Kiva partnership, she requested a loan to buy 4 sacks of flour, 50 liters of cooking oil, 40 kilograms of meat and 6 sacks of potatoes for the filling. She would like to use any remaining funds to buy fire wood to fry the pirozhki because in winter the market does not have any electricity during the day. Parvina is very hopeful about getting a Kiva loan and extends her thanks in advance for the help.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

loans.use: Buying  ingredients & heating supplies for  the business

loans.name: Norm

texts.en: Mr. Norm S., 37, is married with four children and lives with his wife in Batambong province, Cambodia. He supports his family by driving a motor-taxi and makes about $4 a day. His wife stays at home cooking and looking after the family. But Mr. S. and his wife hope to raise their family's income by using this loan to buy a stall in the local market from which she can sell a variety of fruits.

loans.use: To buy a stand in the local market from which to sell a variety of fruits.

loans.name: Thi Chanh

texts.vi:
Mrs. Chanh, 32 years old, is married with two children. Her husband is a brick layer and she raises pigs. Sometimes she sells vegetable from her home garden at the market. She would like to apply for a loan of 150USD to buy more piglets. She plans to spend the income from both husband and wife less so she can make the repayments timely.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Chanh, 32 tuổi, có chồng và 2 con. Chồng chị làm thợ xây, còn chị chăn nuôi lợn ở nhà và thỉnh thoảng đi chợ bán rau nhà trồng được. Chị rất thích vay của chương trình Tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì hình thức trả góp hàng tuần vì vậy Chị vay 2006000đ về để thêm vốn mua lợn giống. Thu nhập hàng ngày từ tiền công của chồng chị đi làm và tiền bán rau hàng ngày chị tiết kiệm chi tiêu để hoàn trả.

loans.use: Buy piglets

loans.name: Thi Nga

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nga, 33 years old, is married with two children. She makes tofu then sells at the market near her home. That earns her 3USD a day in average. The by product from tofu making is used as feed for few dozens of pigs. Her two children are in school, first level. Her husband is a brick layer specializing in building temple. She’s never taken out any loan since most banks require credit and she has none. Now she is applying loan with Binh Minh because its requirements are easy. She plans to save and make repayments timely.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Nga, 33 tuổi, có chồng và 2 con. Chị làm đậu phụ bán hàng ngày ở chợ gần nhà, mỗi ngày thu nhập từ bán đậu chị cũng lãi 50000đ. Tận dụng bã đậu, chị chăn nuôi thêm vài chục con lợn. Chị vay vốn về mua đỗ để làm đậu dần vì mua nhiều chị sẽ được giảm giá. Hai con chị đang học cấp 1, chồng chị làm thợ xây chuyên đi xây dựng các đền chùa. Trước kia chị chưa từng tham gia vay vốn ở đâu vì chị rất ngại làm các thủ tục. Tuy nhiên khi nghe thấy chương trình cho vay vốn không cần thế chấp, chị đã mạnh dạn tham gia. Chị đã có kế hoạch chi tiêu cụ thể hơn để tiết kiệm trả dần.

loans.use: Buy bean to make tofu

loans.name: Ay

texts.en:
Mrs. Ay O., 29, is the mother of one child who works making Khmer wine. She earns about $5 a day reselling this wine in a local market. Her husband makes about $3 a day growing pigs on his farm. (Many Cambodians raise pigs and grow wine at the same time, because pigs like to eat scraps from the wine-making process. After they eat the scraps, the pigs become intoxicated, fall asleep and grow very quickly.)

Mrs. Ay O. hopes to use this loan to expand the pen in which her husband keeps his pigs, and to expand her wine-making business. (Only her husband is pictured because Mrs. Ay O. was unavailable when the photo was taken.)

loans.use: to expand the pen which holds his pigs and expand a wine-making business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Mov

texts.en: Mr. Mov C., 56, is the father of nine children who lives in Batambong province, Cambodia. He runs a stand at a busy local market, where he makes about $5 a day selling groceries. His wife stays at home cooking food for the family and caring for their children. One of their children works as a laborer and another is a motor-taxi driver; several are married and now live away from home. Mr. Mov C. hopes to use this loan to buy more groceries to sell to his customers, because demand for his products is strong.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell to his customers.

loans.name: Faizimod

texts.ru:
Faizimod was born in 1966, is married and has 6 children. He has been working in the Dushanbe Food Market for the last 8 years. He owns two stands that sell hot-dogs, sandwiches, pastries and drinks. One stand is run by himself and his two elder daughters. The other is run by his wife and younger daughter Sitora (both are in the photo). His sons buy the food supplies for the two stands. This business has also enabled him to earn enough money to buy a car, which he uses to transport the supplies.

He has been a registered member of our MLF MicronInvest group since September 2007. He received an earlier loan which he used to expand his inventory by buying 4 thermos flasks for tea and coffee, a microwave oven to warm up the hot-dogs and drinking glasses. Right now he is seeking a Kiva loan to buy the next supply of hot-dog buns, sausages, smoked cold cuts, 10 boxes of tea and 5 tins of coffee.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Thi Nhuong

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nhượng, 37 years old, married with 2 children, is an industrious type. Everyday, she goes around to collect, buy and sell scrap metal. She makes from 2-4USD a day. She also raises few pigs besides scrap metal business. She has never taken out any loan and this is her first time. She is confident that she can handle weekly repayment of few dollars. The loan will be used to buy feed for her pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Chị Nhượng, 37 tuổi, chị có chồng và 2 con. Chị là người phụ nữ rất khó, hàng ngày chị đi chợ buôn sắt vụn và thu mua phế liệu.Thu nhập mỗi ngày chị cũng có khoảng từ 40000-60000đ. Ngoài ra chị còn chăn nuôi thêm lợn nái và lợn thịt. Chị chưa từng tham gia vay vốn ở đâu vì sợ rằng mình sẽ không trả được, tuy nhiên khi có cách thức trả mới này chị đã mạnh dạn tham gia vì mỗi tuần hoàn trả vài chục nghìn chị hoàn toàn làm được. She would like to take out a loan to buy more vegetable. She can make weekly payments.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Cô Tuyết, 50 tuổi, cô có chồng và 4 đứa con. Cô đi chợ bán rau, cô đã làm nghề này từ khi còn là con gái. Hàng ngày cô đến chợ sớm để bán rau của nhà và lấy thêm hàng bán. Để mở rộng mặt hàng bán, cô đã vay vốn về để mua thêm một số các loại rau. Cô thường ở chợ bán hàng từ 5h sáng cho đến tận trưa. Thu nhập từ bán rau cũng đủ để cô chi tiêu gia đình và trả dần hàng tuần.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Thi Tu

texts.vi:
Mrs. Tư, 48 years old, has 4 daughters. The family is poor. Farming and raising few live stock are all she does. One of her daughter is a carpenter. She helps the family somewhat. Mrs. Tư has never made any loan from anyone. This is first time she knows about Binh Minh. She would like to apply for a loan to expand the business.

Translated from Vietnamese by ngungo, Kiva volunteer.


Cô Tư, 48 tuổi, có 4 con gái. Nhà cô rất nghèo. Cô chỉ làm ruộng và chăn nuôi tạo thu nhập cho gia đình. Con gái cô đã đi làm nghề mộc, cũng đỡ đần cô phần nào. Cô chưa từng vay vốn ở đâu. Được biết tới những tiện ích của chương trình Tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc, cô mạnh dạn vay để tăng thêm thu nhập, nâng cao đời sống gia đình.

loans.use: Vegetable farming

loans.name: Namunina A(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Robina N.. She is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,100,000 to expand her business. Robina is 38 years old and she is a widow. She has 2 children who are 18 and 20. Each week Robina makes approximately UGX 20,000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to start a poultry business.

Robina is joined in her small group by Margret N., Suzan Namiro, Marret Nabbagala, and Gladys N.. Margret N. is currently in the restaurant business. She is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to buy a refridgerator and furniture. Suzan Namiro is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to re-invest in the stone quary business. Marret Nabbagala is currently in the business of stone quarrying as well and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to add to her stone business. Gladys N. is currently in the restaurant business and is requesting a loan of UGX 300,000 to purchase more foodstuffs.

loans.use: To expand the businesses

loans.name: Savriniso

texts.en:
O. Savriniso is 37 years old. She is married and has three children. The eldest one is 15 years old, while the youngest is 12. 

For the past five years, Savriniso has been earning income selling the fabrics used for making national dresses which in Tajikistan are very beautiful and colorful. They are also an important item of the dowry of any girl. Savriniso is very polite and has a very good taste; she is ready to advise her clients on their choice of fabric for garments for various family occasions.  Savriniso's husband works in the City Telephone Station. He is able to support the family by himself; however, he also supports Savriniso in her intention to contribute to the family's earnings. 

At the moment, Savriniso needs a loan of US$1,000 for a term of 4 months. She plans to spend the loan for purchasing new fabrics in order to generate more income. Savriniso is thankful for support and promises to repay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchase of materials used for making national dresses

loans.name: Namunina A(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Hellen K.. She is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to expand her business. Hellen is a 23 year old widow. Each week Hellen makes approximately UGX 30,000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to buy more land for laying and making bricks.

Hellen is joined in her small group by Florence N., Annet N., Sarah N., and Zam N.. Florence N. is currently in the business of fishing. She is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to to purchase more fishing nets. Annet N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to re-invest in the stone quary business. Sarah N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying as well. She is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to add to her stone business. Zam N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 900,000 to increase her inventory stock.

loans.use: To expand the businesses

loans.name: Alina

texts.en:
Alina is fifty-three-years old and an experienced and clever entrepreneur.  She makes homemade deep-fried chicken, highly spiced sausage pork, and natural juices, which she sells in the Mata Los Indios community of Santo Domingo.  Alina has been running her business for twelve years, and now her delicious fried food  is very famous and much loved in the community.
Alina is a trustworthy person.  A few months she obtained a loan from FSMA that she invested in her business. She needed funds to buy raw materials to keep preparing her food.  The entrepreneur made a prudent use of the loan, and she can repay on time.
Now, Alina is asking for a second loan to buy meat, fresh fruits, spices, plates and other goods to continue offering tasty food to her customers.

loans.use: To purchase goods to keep producing fried food for her clientele.

loans.name: Namunina B(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mary O.. She is currently in the textile business and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to expand her business. Mary is 45 years old and is single. She has 3 children who range in age from 12 to 22. With the extra profits from her loan, Mary hopes to be able to purchase more textile materials.

Mary is joined in her small group by Ronnah B., Lukia M., Fatumah K., and Joyce M.. Ronnah B. is currently in the sand business. She is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to re-invest in her business. Lukia M. currently runs a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 600,000 to increase her inventory stock. Fatumah K. is currently in the restaurant business and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to buy more furniture. Joyce M. is currently in the piggery business. She is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to buy more piglets.

loans.use: To expand the businesses

loans.name: Namunina B(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sarah N.. She is currently in the business of stone quarrying and is requesting a loan of UGX 900,000 to expand her business. Sarah is 38 years old and she is single. She has 2 children who are 8 and 10. Both of her children go to school. Each week Sarah makes approximately UGX 30,000 in profits from her business. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to expand her stone quarry business.

Sarah is joined in her small group by Mayimuna N., Ruth N., Gertrude W., and Christine M.. Mayimuna N. is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to to re-invest in the business. Ruth N. is currently in the business of brick laying as well. She requests a loan of UGX 200,000 to start a sand selling business. Gertrude W. is also in the brick laying business and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to re-invest in the business. Christine M. is currently in the fishing business. She is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to expand her fishing business.

loans.use: To expand the businesses

loans.name: Gloria's Group

texts.en:
This dedicated group of seventeen businesswomen has taken on the name “The Star of the South.” The star represents the importance of the group as a guide star for the women who are trying to improve their businesses and the lives of their families. These women all have separate businesses dedicated to the sales or the making of food and other goods, some sell recyclable goods like plastic, aluminum, and cardboard.

These women have the common goal of not only increasing their businesses, but to also provide the best opportunities for their children. By increasing their businesses they will have the savings to send their children to school and give them opportunities that they themselves were unable to have.

With this loan, the women will buy goods they need to sell including fruits, vegetables, recyclable materials and ingredients to make and sell Chipas, a favorite Paraguayan snack.

loans.use: To buy recyclable materials like cardboard, plastic, aluminum, and other types of metal.  The ingredients to make and sell Chipas, along with oranges, bananas, pineapples, melons, watermelon, apples, various refreshments.  Other merchandise includes cosmetics, linen, and thread.

loans.name: Muminchon

texts.en:
S. Muminchon is 44 years old. Together with his wife, he has raised two children. The eldest one is already married, while the youngest helps his parents in running the family business.

Muminchon and his wife (shown in the photograph) run two sales stands at the local markets. Muminchon has been in this business already for four years. He sells bread, meat products and cooked meats like sausages, boiled sausage, frankfurter, and dairy products, such as cheese and butter. This sales business is the main source of income for the family and brings in a stable profit.   

Muminchon has borrowed from IMON several times in the past, and has proved himself as a reliable and honest client. Currently, he is asking for a loan of US$700 to be repaid in 6 months. Muminchon will use the loan to purchase bread, flour, meat products, and cooked meats for sale.

loans.use: Purchase of bread, flour, and meat products for sale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Grace S. is 44 years old and she is single with three children. Her children are 10, 12, and 18 years old, and she has two other dependents, her grandson and her maid. In 1993 Grace established a tailoring, computer services, and crop-selling business. Grace now seeks a loan in order to purchase material and accessories for her tailoring business, paper and printing cartridges for her computer business, and additional stocks of crops for sale. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA:
SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing whereby SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA will purchase equipment from said client, extend a loan to her, and then lease the same equipment back to her – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; therefore, financial institutions do not consider Tanzanian women to be credit-worthy because they lack tangible assets that could serve as collateral. As a result, Tanzanian women with low income receive poor financial support and meager access to basic needs and services. SELFINA thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase material and accessories for her tailoring business, paper and printing cartridges for her computer business, and additional stocks of crops for sale.

loans.name: Namunina B(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Deborah A.. She is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan of UGX 900,000 to expand her business. Deborah is 25 years old and she is single. Each week Deborah makes approximately UGX 35,000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to start a livestock business.

Deborah is joined in her small group by Ruth N., Hasifah N., Margret N., and Gladys Z.. Ruth N. is currently in the business of stone quarrying. She is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to re-invest in the business. Hasifah N. is currently in the business of selling fruits and vegeables. She is requesting a loan of UGX 200,000 to increase her inventory stock. Margret N. is currently in the business of brick laying as well and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to re-invest in the brick business. Gladys Z. is currently in the restaurant business and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to buy more food warmers.

loans.use: To expand the businesses and make more profits

loans.name: Mujeres En La Lucha Group

texts.en:
The present committee of nineteen women have come together to form “Women in the Fight,” and offer support to one another in their fight against poverty. Each of these women have families to support, and bills to pay, and they are doing everything they can to keep their businesses and incomes growing. This committee began when a woman from another group from the town of Yka’a, decided that help was needed in a nearby neighborhood.

They received their first loan from Fundación Paraguaya and have repaid on time and in full. These business women are now asking for a loan to help increase their amount of goods sold, and to keep their shops stocked with goods like fruit, baking goods, clothing items and cleaning products.

loans.use: To buy refreshments like soda, beer, bananas, pineapples, pears, watermelons, oranges, laundry detergent, material, linen, thread, pants, blouses, and t-shirts.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is twenty-four-years old and a mother of three children.  She lives in Mata Los Indios, in the community of Santo Domingo.
Yolanda sells a collection of pants, shoes, and underwear to men and women of her community.  Yolanda explains that twice a month, she has to take a trip outside the capital in order to get the garments at low prices.  This way, she makes sure she will have good profits.  Currently, her products are in high demand, but she is in short supply.  Therefore, Yolanda is requesting a loan (the second loan she will take from FSMA) to buy clothing in bulk, in order to satisfy her customers’ needs.

loans.use: Purchase clothing to supply a small business.

loans.name: Kitega F(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Margret N.. She is currently in the business of laundry and drycleaning. She is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to buy more laundry equipment. Margret is 28 years old and she is married with a husband that works as well. She has a daughter aged 10 who attends school. Each week, Margret makes approximately UGX 30,000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to start a poultry business.

Margret is joined in her small group by Suzan M., Rose N., Irene N., and Fatumah N.. Suzan M. is currently in the business of running a nursery school and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to construct a new classroom. Rose N. is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to expand her brick business. Irene N. is currently in the business of selling used clothing. She is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to increase her stock. Fatumah N. is currently in the salon business and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to buy more hairdryers.

loans.use: To invest in the businesses

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Irene M. is 20 years old and she is married with two children. Her children are 2 and 4 years old, respectively. In 2000 Irene established a crop-selling, fish-selling, and coffee business. Irene now seek a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of crops, fish, and coffee in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA:
SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing whereby SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA will purchase equipment from said client, extend a loan to her, and then lease the same equipment back to her – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; therefore, financial institutions do not consider Tanzanian women to be credit-worthy because they lack tangible assets that could serve as collateral. As a result, Tanzanian women with low income receive poor financial support and meager access to basic needs and services. SELFINA thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of crops, fish, and coffee in bulk.

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Para Triunfar Group

texts.en:
This committee of seventeen women in the San Pedro neighborhood has been one of the first that have formed. They are entitled, "Women United to Triumph,” and have helped start other similar support groups in the neighborhood. Their goal is to triumph over poverty and help others overcome economic hardships as well. The businesses of these women include convenience stores, tailor shops, hair salons, clothing, cosmetics, and other various merchandise sales.

The loan will be used in the purchase of goods to grow their businesses. Material, thread, buttons, elastic, flour, breads, canned goods, drinks, clothing items, hair and cosmetic products are needed for the women’s businesses. Together they work to uplift one another and increase their profits.

loans.use: To buy clothing, hair and cosmetic products, laundry detergent, body soap, flour, breads, canned goods, and sewing goods.

loans.name: Kitega F(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Robinah N.. She is currently in the business of running a grocery store and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to increase her inventory stock. Robinah is 48 years old and she is single. She has 2 children who are 18 and 22. Both of her children go to school. Each week Robinah makes approximately UGX 30,000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to re-invest in her grocery business.

Robinah is joined in her small group by Sylvia L., Sauda Z., Alice N., and Sarah N.. Sylvia L. is currently in the business of selling second hand clothes. She is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to add to her stock. Sauda Z. is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to expand her business. Alice N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop. She is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to buy a refridgerator. Sarah N. is currently in the business of selling used clothing and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To expand the businesses

loans.name: Asubisye

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Asubisye C. is 35 years old and she is married with three children, aged 10, 13 and 16 years old. In 1995 Asubisye established a clothing shop and she now seeks a loan in order to purchase clothes in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA:
SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing whereby SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. As a result, Tanzanian women with low income receive poor financial support and meager access to basic needs and services. SELFINA thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothes in bulk.

loans.name: San Cayetano Group

texts.en:
From the neighborhood of Villa Bonita, a group of fifteen women have come together to form a business group called “San Cayetano.” After seeing the success of another group of women in the town of Villa Elisa, San Cayetano decided to unite and begin their group. Together they have been successful because all the women involved are mothers who need to continue increasing their profits in order to support their families.

The welfare of their children along with their dedication to raising their standard of living is their reason for joining together and asking for a loan. Most of the women have their own independent businesses, but not all of them have their own store. It is one of the future goals of the committee of San Cayetano that every woman has her own store. With the loan, the women will invest in goods like food products, clothing sales, linen, and machinery and store repairs.

loans.use: To invest in machinery repair, improving the store infrastructure, and buying various articles for the businesses like buying convenience stores, food, charcoal, and merchandise for traveling saleswomen.

loans.name: Kitega F(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Alice N.. She is currently in the salon business and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to buy a hairdryer and steamer. Alice is 40 years old and is married with one child, who is 10 years old. Each week Alice makes approximately UGX 25,000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to start a poultry business.

Alice is joined in her small group by Faith N., Rebecca N., Nulu N., and Christine N.. Faith N. is currently in the charcoal selling business and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to add to her inventory stock. Rebecca N. is currently in the business of selling fresh foods. She is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to purchase more food to sell. Nulu N. is currently in the business of brick laying. She is requesting a loan of UGX 600,000 to expand her brick business. Christine N. is also currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to re-invest in brick her business.

loans.use: To increase businee capital

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Annamary

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Annamary M. is a 52-year-old widow with four children. Her children are between the ages of 19 and 34 years old. In 2004 Annamary established a bar and she now seeks a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of beer, liquor, and soft drinks. Undoubtedly, Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or 'words" in the world. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of "bar" selling Coke, Fanta, and Guinness; Annamary notes that Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the less-populated areas, but she is sure that Pepsi is working on expanding into those areas too!). The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing, which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture regardless of whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd. in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

About SELFINA:
SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing whereby SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA will purchase equipment from said client, extend a loan to her, and then lease the same equipment back to her – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; therefore, financial institutions do not consider Tanzanian women to be credit-worthy because they lack tangible assets that could serve as collateral. As a result, Tanzanian women with low income receive poor financial support and meager access to basic needs and services. SELFINA thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer, liquor, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria E. is a fifty-four-year-old mother of four. Her children are grown, and help Maria and her husband with their business selling charcoal to different convenience stores and markets. They sell in the mornings, and in the afternoon they package the charcoal. They also have another small business they are expanding, which is gathering cardboard to sell to a nearby factory.

The next step in their business is to save enough money to buy a small truck. This would make the transportation of their goods simpler and faster, which would allow them to increase their profits. With the loan, the couple will buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.use: To buy charcoal, to sell to different stores and markets.

loans.name: Twelusigwe

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Twelusigwe K. is 45 years old and she is married with six children. Her children are between the ages of 10 and 24 years old and she has one other dependent, her house boy. In 1997 Twelusigwe established a pharmacy and she now seeks a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of medicine. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA:

As a result, Tanzanian women with low income receive poor financial support and meager access to basic needs and services. SELFINA thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of medicine in bulk

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.en:
The woman’s business group, “The Hope of the East,” is located in the town of Ciudad del Este and are a band of neighbors who have come together to support each of their individual businesses. These women own businesses selling ropes and groceries like tobacco, garlic, and refreshments. Together they are working to increase profits and support their families.

These women are asking for a loan together to help increase their business profits. With the money they will purchase various groceries and ropes for their individual businesses.

loans.use: To buy rope, tobacco, garlic, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Mary M. is a 33-year old widow with two children. Her children are 8 and 10 years old, respectively. In 2002 Mary established a tailoring business and she now seeks a loan in order to purchase material and accessories for her tailoring business. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA:
SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.
